dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, so you know, we've been talking a lot about market volatility lately, and it got me thinking about, uh, safe havens.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, so you know, we've been talking a lot about market volatility lately, and it got me thinking about, uh, safe havens.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, A. I mean, traditionally, when people are worried, like, all roads led to US Treasuries, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, A. I mean, traditionally, when people are worried, like, all roads led to U S Treasuries, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Historically, the safe haven par excellence was the United States, in the form of Treasury bonds backed by the full faith and credit of the US government. As one investment strategist put it back in 2012, When people are worried, all road lead to Treasuries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. I remember during the 2007 real estate bubble burst, even though the US was the epicenter of the crisis, capital just *flooded* in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. I remember during the two thousand seven real estate bubble burst, even though the U S was the epicenter of the crisis, capital just flooded in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bursting of the US real-estate bubble in 2007 offers a case in point. No one doubted that the US was the epicenter of the global financial crisis. But rather than flee the US, capital actually flooded into it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, like, half a trillion dollars in three months of 2009! It was wild. Some of it was for banks needing cash, but mostly, it was just sheer fear. The US was seen as the safest bet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, half a trillion dollars in three months of two thousand nine! It was wild. Some of it was for banks needing cash, but mostly, it was just sheer fear. The U S was seen as the safest bet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the last three months of 2008, net purchases of US assets reached a half-trillion dollars three times more than that of the preceding nine months combined.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But that was, uh, before Donald Trump, wasn't it? He's kind of... I don't know, he's undermined confidence in the dollar quite a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that was, uh, before Donald Trump, wasn't it? He's kind of... I don't know, he's undermined confidence in the dollar quite a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But this was before the arrival US President Donald Trump, who has managed to undermine confidence in the dollar to an unprecedented degree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. I mean, abandoning fiscal responsibility, attacking allies... it's a departure. And even before Trump, you know, there was that S&P downgrade in 2011 because of the debt ceiling standoff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. I mean, abandoning fiscal responsibility, attacking allies... it's a departure. And even before Trump, you know, there was that S and P downgrade in twenty eleven because of the debt ceiling standoff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to abandoning any notion of fiscal responsibility, Trump has spent his first two years in office attacking international institutions and picking fights with US allies. To be sure, even before Trump, confidence in the dollar suffered a blow in 2011, when Standard & Poors downgraded Treasury securities by one notch in response to a near-shutdown of the US government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, that was a big deal. And now, uh, with all these government shutdowns, like, three in 2018 alone, for *the wall*? Investors have even more reason to be nervous.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, that was a big deal. And now, uh, with all these government shutdowns, like, three in twenty eighteen alone, for the wall? Investors have even more reason to be nervous.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018 alone, the US government was shut down three times, and it remains in a partial shutdown to this day, owing to Trumps demand for funds to build a big, beautiful wall on the border with Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. So, it begs the question, if not the US, then where do investors go now for a safe haven?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. So, it begs the question, if not the U S, then where do investors go now for a safe haven?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the Eurozone seems like a logical next step; after the dollar, it's the second most used currency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the Eurozone seems like a logical next step; after the dollar, it's the second most used currency.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After the dollar, the euro is the worlds most widely used currency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It does, but, um, Europe has its own issues, right? Slowing growth, especially Germany, and like, Italy's banking crisis is always a concern. And Brexit just messes everything up, so the UK is out too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does, but, um, Europe has its own issues, right? Slowing growth, especially Germany, and like, Italy's banking crisis is always a concern. And Brexit just messes everything up, so the U K is out too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economic growth is slowing, not least in Germany, and the risk of a banking crisis in Italy the eurozones fourth-largest economy looms on the horizon. Worse still is the uncertainty over Brexit, which could prove highly disruptive if the United Kingdom crashes out of the European Union without a divorce agreement. Needless to say, Britain, too, can be ruled out as a safe haven, at least until the Brexit fiasco is resolved.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the Brexit fiasco. What about, uh, Switzerland? The Swiss Franc?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the Brexit fiasco. What about, uh, Switzerland? The Swiss Franc?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Too small, unfortunately. Their financial markets just aren't big enough to absorb all that capital.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Too small, unfortunately. Their financial markets just aren't big enough to absorb all that capital.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though its attractions are obvious, Switzerlands financial markets are simply too small to serve as an adequate substitute for the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, that leaves Japan, maybe? Huge bond market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, that leaves Japan, maybe? Huge bond market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That leaves Japan. With its abundant supply of government bonds, it is the biggest single market for public debt outside the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, Japan... *super* high debt-to-GDP, over 230%! Compare that to, like, 110% in the US.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, Japan... super high debt-to-G D P, over two hundred thirty percent! Compare that to, like, one hundred ten percent in the U S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The question for portfolio managers, though, is whether it is really safe to invest in a country where government debt exceeds 230% of GDP. For comparison, the public debt-to-GDP ratio in the US is around 88%

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. Even though domestic savers hold a lot of it, their economy's been stagnant for ages, and it's an aging country. Where would they find the resources, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Even though domestic savers hold a lot of it, their economy's been stagnant for ages, and it's an aging country. Where would they find the resources, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Admittedly, the market for Japanese government debt is more stable than most, owing to the fact that much of it is held by domestic savers (which is to say, it is safely tucked under the mattress). But Japan is an aging country with an economy that has remained almost stagnant for a quarter-century. Investors would be right to wonder where it will find the resources to continue servicing its massive debt overhang.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then there's China, which has a massive market, but it's so tightly controlled. It's, uh, the opposite of a safe haven.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then there's China, which has a massive market, but it's so tightly controlled. It's, uh, the opposite of a safe haven.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And then there is China, with the worlds third-largest national market for public debt. ... But the Chinese market is so tightly controlled that it is essentially the opposite of a safe haven.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So essentially, we're saying, like, safe ports are becoming really scarce.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So essentially, we're saying, like, safe ports are becoming really scarce.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With secure ports becoming scarce, investors will become increasingly jittery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And that means investors are going to be super jittery, moving funds at the slightest sign of trouble. Which, uh, just adds to market volatility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And that means investors are going to be super jittery, moving funds at the slightest sign of trouble. Which, uh, just adds to market volatility.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They will be inclined to move funds at the slightest sign of danger, which will add substantially to market volatility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it sounds like this rough patch, you know, it might be here to stay for a while.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it sounds like this rough patch, you know, it might be here to stay for a while.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Todays rough patch is probably here to stay.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It certainly seems that way, A.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It certainly seems that way, A.
